<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 186, 905, 202]]<|/det|>
0625/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 208, 905, 223]]<|/det|>
February/March 2019  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 229, 905, 243]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 588, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 311, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 458, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 517, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 548, 358, 563]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 562, 630, 578]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> Which row shows the best choice of measuring instruments to obtain accurate values for the distances shown? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 116, 730, 305]]<|/det|>

Neither liquid X or liquid Y mixes with mercury. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 114, 655, 349]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 361, 920, 394]]<|/det|> Which row compares the pressure exerted by liquid X and by liquid Y on the mercury, and the density of liquid X and the density of liquid Y? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 405, 850, 551]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 578, 104, 596]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 578, 767, 597]]<|/det|> Gas molecules exert a pressure when they collide with the walls of a container. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 609, 348, 626]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 638, 134, 656]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 638, 922, 670]]<|/det|> They experience a change in force which exerts a pressure equal to momentum \(\times\) area on the walls. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 688, 134, 706]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 687, 922, 730]]<|/det|> They experience a change in force which exerts a pressure equal to momentum on the area walls. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 733, 131, 752]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 733, 922, 765]]<|/det|> They experience a change in momentum which exerts a pressure equal to force \(\times\) area on the walls. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 784, 133, 802]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 783, 922, 821]]<|/det|> They experience a change in momentum which exerts a pressure equal to force on the area walls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 710, 92]]<|/det|> A thermometer has graduations which start at \(- 10^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) and end at \(110^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 98, 767, 153]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 166, 801, 186]]<|/det|> What is the lower fixed point and what is the upper fixed point of the Celsius scale? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 196, 487, 344]]<|/det|>
lower fixed point
/°C		upper fixed point

D0110
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 370, 107, 389]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 370, 920, 406]]<|/det|> A \(1\mathrm{kg}\) block of aluminium requires more thermal energy to raise its temperature by \(1^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) than a \(1\mathrm{kg}\) block of copper requires. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 416, 220, 435]]<|/det|> Why is this? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 444, 134, 463]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 444, 672, 464]]<|/det|> Aluminium is a better conductor of thermal energy than copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 471, 131, 490]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 471, 677, 490]]<|/det|> Aluminium is a poorer conductor of thermal energy than copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 497, 131, 515]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 497, 638, 515]]<|/det|> Aluminium has a higher specific heat capacity than copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 522, 133, 541]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 522, 631, 541]]<|/det|> Aluminium has a lower specific heat capacity than copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 567, 106, 585]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 567, 500, 585]]<|/det|> Four campers are warming their food on a fire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 597, 818, 616]]<|/det|> They use different rods, each of the same dimensions, to hold their food near the fire. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 625, 645, 789]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 797, 750, 816]]<|/det|> Which material is the best choice to prevent their hands from getting too hot? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 826, 138, 845]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 826, 240, 845]]<|/det|> aluminium <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 854, 136, 872]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 854, 212, 872]]<|/det|> copper <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 880, 136, 898]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 880, 196, 898]]<|/det|> steel <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 907, 136, 924]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 907, 200, 924]]<|/det|> wood

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
Two metal cans are identical, except that one has a shiny silver outer surface and the other has a dull black outer surface. They each have \(300\mathrm{g}\) of water at \(80^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) sealed inside them. They are both in a vacuum, in the darkness of outer space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 618, 151]]<|/det|>
How does the temperature of the water in each one change?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 161, 134, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 161, 376, 179]]<|/det|>
Neither one will cool down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 189, 134, 206]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 188, 740, 205]]<|/det|>
The water in the black can cools more slowly than that in the shiny can.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 215, 134, 233]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 214, 740, 232]]<|/det|>
The water in the shiny can cools more slowly than that in the black can.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 240, 134, 258]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 240, 470, 257]]<|/det|>
They both cool down at the same rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 285, 104, 303]]<|/det|>
<label>21</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 285, 603, 303]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 314, 631, 332]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 644, 390, 662]]<|/det|>

6.7 cm/s

<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 672, 557, 689]]<|/det|>
60 cm/s

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 672, 735, 689]]<|/det|>
120 cm/s

The air pressure at that point increases and then decreases 300 times every second. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 116, 494, 134]]<|/det|> Which descriptions apply to this sound wave? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 145, 707, 274]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 303, 106, 320]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 303, 920, 336]]<|/det|> A boy stands \(150\mathrm{m}\) from a wall. He claps and when he hears the echo, he immediately claps again. He continues this for some time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 350, 920, 380]]<|/det|> Another student has a stop-watch. She starts the watch on the first clap and stops it on the eleventh clap. The watch reads 10.0 s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 393, 692, 410]]<|/det|> Which value do her measurements give for the speed of sound in air? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 420, 133, 438]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 420, 225, 438]]<|/det|> 150 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 420, 298, 438]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 420, 393, 438]]<|/det|> 170 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 420, 468, 438]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 420, 560, 438]]<|/det|> 300 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 420, 636, 438]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 420, 727, 438]]<|/det|> 330 m/s <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 465, 106, 484]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 465, 875, 484]]<|/det|> The ends of three metal rods are tested by holding end Q of rod 1 close to the others in turn. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 491, 635, 610]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 625, 336, 642]]<|/det|> The results are as follows. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 656, 297, 673]]<|/det|> End Q attracts end R. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 679, 297, 696]]<|/det|> End Q attracts end S. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 701, 297, 718]]<|/det|> End Q attracts end T. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 724, 288, 740]]<|/det|> End Q repels end U. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 754, 426, 771]]<|/det|> Which of the metal rods is a magnet? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 782, 134, 800]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 782, 237, 800]]<|/det|> rod 1 only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 809, 133, 826]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 809, 282, 826]]<|/det|> rod 1 and rod 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 835, 133, 853]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 835, 282, 852]]<|/det|> rod 1 and rod 3 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 861, 133, 878]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 861, 237, 878]]<|/det|> rod 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 875, 91]]<|/det|>
A metal sphere is charged by induction. There are four stages W, X, Y and Z in this process.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 101, 584, 120]]<|/det|>
W a charged rod is brought near to the sphere

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 127, 401, 146]]<|/det|>
X the sphere is earthed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 153, 609, 172]]<|/det|>
Y the charged rod is taken away from the sphere

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 179, 490, 198]]<|/det|>
Z the earth connection is removed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 209, 499, 228]]<|/det|>
In which order are the four stages carried out?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 237, 134, 255]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 237, 326, 255]]<|/det|>
W \(\rightarrow\) X \(\rightarrow\) Y \(\rightarrow\) Z

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 265, 134, 282]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 265, 326, 282]]<|/det|>
W \(\rightarrow\) X \(\rightarrow\) Z \(\rightarrow\) Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 292, 134, 311]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 292, 326, 310]]<|/det|>
Z \(\rightarrow\) W \(\rightarrow\) X \(\rightarrow\) Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 319, 134, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 319, 326, 337]]<|/det|>
X \(\rightarrow\) Z \(\rightarrow\) W \(\rightarrow\) Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 364, 106, 383]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 537, 107, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 537, 702, 555]]<|/det|> The current in a kettle is 10 A and the kettle is protected by a 13 A fuse. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 567, 625, 585]]<|/det|> The owner of the kettle replaces the 13 A fuse with a 3 A fuse. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 597, 500, 615]]<|/det|> What happens when the kettle is switched on? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 625, 134, 644]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 625, 556, 644]]<|/det|> The fuse melts and the kettle might be damaged. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 653, 134, 670]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 653, 526, 670]]<|/det|> The fuse melts and the kettle is undamaged. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 679, 134, 696]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 679, 594, 696]]<|/det|> The fuse does not melt and the kettle works correctly. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 705, 134, 723]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 705, 562, 723]]<|/det|> The fuse does not melt but the kettle fails to work. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 749, 107, 768]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 749, 744, 766]]<|/det|> Which statement about the direction of a magnetic field at a point is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 777, 133, 796]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 777, 683, 796]]<|/det|> It is the direction of the force on a north pole placed at that point. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 804, 133, 822]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 804, 687, 822]]<|/det|> It is the direction of the force on a south pole placed at that point. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 831, 133, 850]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 831, 725, 848]]<|/det|> It is the direction of the force on a positive charge placed at that point. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 857, 133, 875]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 857, 732, 875]]<|/det|> It is the direction of the force on a negative charge placed at that point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 104, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 537, 90]]<|/det|> A current-carrying coil is placed in a magnetic field. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 98, 682, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 259, 437, 278]]<|/det|> Which effect does the coil experience? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 288, 138, 306]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 288, 308, 306]]<|/det|> a change in shape <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 314, 138, 331]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 314, 312, 331]]<|/det|> a change in weight <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 138, 358]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 339, 287, 357]]<|/det|> a resultant force <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 365, 131, 384]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 365, 280, 383]]<|/det|> a turning effect <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 409, 106, 428]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 409, 398, 428]]<|/det|> What are isotopes of an element? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 438, 133, 457]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 438, 677, 457]]<|/det|> atoms of a different element with a different number of neutrons <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 464, 133, 483]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 464, 668, 483]]<|/det|> atoms of a different element with a different number of protons <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 490, 133, 509]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 490, 670, 508]]<|/det|> atoms of the same element with a different number of neutrons <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 517, 133, 536]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 517, 660, 536]]<|/det|> atoms of the same element with a different number of protons <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 561, 106, 579]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 920, 594]]<|/det|> A radioactive isotope of carbon \(^{14}\mathrm{C}\) decays by beta emission to give an isotope of nitrogen \(^{14}\mathrm{N}\) and a beta particle. The equation for the reaction is shown. <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 610, 613, 641]]<|/det|> \[^{14}_{X}\mathrm{C}\rightarrow ^{14}_{7}\mathrm{N} + ^{9}_{7}\mathrm{B}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 656, 384, 675]]<|/det|> What is the value of X and of Y? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 686, 359, 816]]<|/det|>
XY
A6-1
B61
C8-1
D81

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 447, 88]]<|/det|>
A beta particle is a fast moving electron.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 707, 120]]<|/det|>
Which statement explains how beta particles are emitted from an atom?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 129, 811, 147]]<|/det|>
An electron is emitted as a beta particle from an inner electron shell of the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 134, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 155, 811, 173]]<|/det|>
An electron is emitted as a beta particle from an outer electron shell of the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 131, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 182, 808, 199]]<|/det|>
A neutron changes into a proton and a beta particle is emitted from the nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 209, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 208, 808, 225]]<|/det|>
A proton changes into a neutron and a beta particle is emitted from the nucleus.
